column2: Friends. Family. We are gathered to celebrate here today the joyous\nunion of Ross and Emily. (Time lapse) Now Ross, repeat after me. I Ross...'
I Ross...'
Take thee, Emily...'
Take thee, Rachel...(All his friends have looks of shock on their faces.\nHe realizes what he said. Quickly he says.) Emily. (A slight chuckle.) Emily.'
(Looking and feeling awkward. he looks towards Emily.) Uhh...Shall I\ngo on?'
(To the woman sitting in front of her) He-he said Rachel, right? Do you\nthink I should go up there?'
Yes, yes, do go on.'
I think we\xc2\x92d better start again. Ross, repeat after me. I,\nRoss\xc2\x85'
I, Ross\xc2\x85'
Take thee, EM-I-LY\xc2\x85'
Take thee, (Glares at the Minister) Emily. (Chuckles) Like\nthere\xc2\x92d be anybody else. (Emily is glaring at him.)'
As my lawfully wedded wife, in sickness and in health, till death\nparts us.'
As my lawfully wedded wife, in sickness and in health, until death parts\nus. Really, I do. Emily. (Points at her.)'

May I have the rings? (He is given the rings) Emily, place this ring
on Ross\xc2\x92s finger as a symbol of your bond everlasting. (She jams the ring onto his
finger) Ross, place this ring in Emily\xc2\x92s hand as a symbol of the love that encircles
you forever.'
Happy too.'
Ross and Emily have made their declarations and it gives me great\npleasure to declare them husband and wife.'
Yay!'
You may kiss the bride.'
(To Mr. Geller) This is worse than when he married the lesbian.'
Just keep smiling.'
Okay.'
Well, that went well. Yeah.'
It could\xc2\x92ve been worse, he could\xc2\x92ve shot her.'
(laughs) That uh, that was pretty funny. Wasn\xc2\x92t it?'
(Yelling from inside the bathroom) You\xc2\x92ve spoiled everything!\nIt\xc2\x92s like a nightmare! My friends and family are out there! How can I face them?! How\ncan you do this to me?!'
(To the gang) Hey, no matter what happens with Ross and Emily, we still\nget cake right?'

(exiting the bathroom) That-that-that\xc2\x92s all right, no honey, you take\nyour time sweetie. I\xc2\x92ll be right out here. (She slams the door in his face, to the\ngang) She\xc2\x92s just fixing her makeup.'
I hate you!!'
And, I love you!! (He walks into the living room)'
Boy, bad time to say the wrong name, huh Ross?'
That\xc2\x92s true, thanks dad. (To All) People should be dancing! Huh? Hey,\nthis is a party! Come on! Joey, dance!! (He starts to dance but stops when no one else\njoins him.)'
Yes, Waltham interiors.'
(On the phone, in New York) Uh, hello, this is Ross Geller\xc2\x92s\npersonal physician, Dr. Philange.'
Who?'

Yeah, I\xc2\x92ve discovered that Ross forgot to take his brain medicine,\nuh, now without it, uh, in the brain of Ross, uh women\xc2\x92s names are interchangeable,\nthrough-through no fault of his own.'
Oh my God, Phoebe.'
No, not Phoebe, Dr. Philange. Oh no! You have it too!'
Hello?'
Hey.'
Hey.'
Oh wow, I hope you don\xc2\x92t take this the wrong way but, I know we\nhad plans to meet up tonight and, ugh, I\xc2\x92m just kinda worried about what it might do\nto our friendship.'
I know. How could we have let this happen?'
Seven times!'
Ugh! Well, y\xc2\x92know, we were away\xc2\x85'
In a foreign, romantic country\xc2\x85'
I blame London.'
Bad London! (Takes a spoon and smacks the turkey.)'
So look umm, while we\xc2\x92re st-still in London, I mean, we can keep\ndoing it right?'
Well, I don\xc2\x92t see that we have a choice. But, when we\xc2\x92re\nback home, we don\xc2\x92t do it.'
Only here.'
Y\xc2\x92know, I saw a wine cellar downstairs\xc2\x85'
I\xc2\x92ll meet you there in two minutes.'
Okay! '
Mon, honey, I gotta ask you something.'
(impatiently) Now?'
Ross said my name up there, I mean, come on, I just can\xc2\x92t pretend\nthat didn\xc2\x92t happen can I?'
Oh, I-I don\xc2\x92t know.'
Monica, what should I do?'
Just uh, do the right thing. (Uses some breath spray)'
What?'
Toe the line. Thread the needle. Think outside the box! (Tries to leave,\nbut is stopped by Rachel.)'
Whoa, wait, listen, I think I\xc2\x92m just gonna talk to Ross about what\nhe think it meant.'
Wait. Rachel, no, he\xc2\x92s married. Married! If you don\xc2\x92t realize\nthat, I can\xc2\x92t help you.'
Okay, you\xc2\x92re right. You\xc2\x92re right. You can\xc2\x92t help me.'
Jack, is it all our fault? Were we bad parents?'
(walking by) Yes.'
Oh yeah, well who serves steak when there\xc2\x92s no place to sit, I\nmean how are you supposed to eat this?'
Hey, what\xc2\x92s up? (He has solved the problem of eating the steak,\nhe\xc2\x92s eating it with his hands.)'
Where were you? We were supposed to meet in the wine cellar?'
Forget it, that\xc2\x92s off.'
Why?!'
(drunkenly) The next tour of the wine cellar will plan in two in-in\nminutes\xc2\x85'
Joey, what are you doing? You promised Phoebe you wouldn\xc2\x92t eat meat\nuntil she has the babies!'
Well, I figured we\xc2\x92re in another country, so it doesn\xc2\x92t count.'
That\xc2\x92s true.'
The man\xc2\x92s got a point.'
Oh, hi!'
Hi!'
Hi. Sorry, things aren\xc2\x92t working out so well.'
Oh no! It could be better, but it\xc2\x92s gonna be okay, right?'

Oh yeah! Of course, I mean, she\xc2\x92s gonna get over this, y\xc2\x92know?
I mean, so you said my name! Y\xc2\x92know you just said it \xc2\x91cause you saw me there, if
you\xc2\x92d have seen a circus freak, you would\xc2\x92ve said, "I take thee circus
freak." Y\xc2\x92know, it didn\xc2\x92t mean anything, it\xc2\x92s just a mistake. It
didn\xc2\x92t mean anything. Right?'
No! No! Of course it didn\xc2\x92t mean anything! I mean, uh well, I can\nunderstand why Emily would think it meant something, y\xc2\x92know, because-because it was\nyou\xc2\x85'
Right\xc2\x85'
But it absolutely didn\xc2\x92t. (Yelling towards the bathroom) It\ndidn\xc2\x92t!! It didn\xc2\x92t!!'
(approaching) Ross, hey, the band\xc2\x92s ready outside for your first\ndance with Emily, so\xc2\x85'
(sarcastic) Oh! Oh-oh, the band\xc2\x92s ready! Well, I-I-we gotta do what\nthe band says\xc2\x97I don\xc2\x92t care about the stupid band!!'
You spit on me man! (Wipes his face.)'
Look, I\xc2\x92m sorry.'
Emily is kinda taking a long time, huh?'
(laughs) Y\xc2\x92know when I locked myself in the bathroom at my wedding,\nit was because I was trying to pop the window out of the frame.'
Oh, right!'
Get the hell out of there, y\xc2\x92know?'
(Bangs on the bathroom door) Emily? Emily? I\xc2\x92m coming in. (He opens\nthe door to reveal that the window is gone, along with Emily.)'
Well, look at that, same thing.'
Listen, in the middle of everything if I scream the word,\n"Yippee!" just ignore me.'
Oh my God, Rachel! Hi!'
Oh, hello Rachel.'

Ross said my name. Okay? My name. Ross said my name up there that\nobviously means that he still loves me! (They both just stare at her.) Okay, don\xc2\x92t\nbelieve me, I know I\xc2\x92m right\xc2\x97do you guys want to go downstairs and get a drink?'
Yes, we do. But, we have to change first.'
Yes, I want to change. And why-why don\xc2\x92t you go down and get us a\ntable?'
Yeah, we\xc2\x92ll be down in like five minutes.'
(elbows him) Fifteen minutes.'
Okay.'
Hello? Oh, Pheebs! (To them) It\xc2\x92s Phoebe!'
Oh, yay\xc2\x85'
Great\xc2\x85'
Hi!'
Hi, so what happened?'
Well, Ross said my name.'
Yeah, I know, but I don\xc2\x92t think that means anything.'

Okay, Pheebs, y\xc2\x92know what, let\xc2\x92s look at this objectively all\nright? Ninth grade, right? The obsession starts. All right? The summer after ninth grade\nhe sees me in a two-piece for the first time, his obsession begins to grow. So then\xc2\x85'
(To Monica) Hey, listen, why don\xc2\x92t we go change in my room?'
But my clothes are\xc2\x97ohh! (They both leave.)'
Wow, you look\xc2\x85'
No time for that!'
Hey, dude, let me in. I got a girl out here!'
Well, I\xc2\x92ve got a girl in here.'
No you don\xc2\x92t, I just saw you go in there with Monica!'
Well, we\xc2\x92re-we\xc2\x92re hanging out in here!'
Look, which one of us is gonna be having sex in there, me or you?'
Well, I suppose I\xc2\x92d have to say you!! But, what if we\xc2\x92re\nwatching a movie in here?'
Which we are, and-and we already paid for it. It\xc2\x92s My Giant!'
My Giant? I love that movie!'
You really think this is okay?'
Well, Ross and Emily aren\xc2\x92t gonna use it.'
Oh, it\xc2\x92s so beautiful. Ohh! Y\xc2\x92know, I-I don\xc2\x92t know if I\nfeel right about this.'

Oh Mon-Mon-Mon-Mon-look, this is the honeymoon suite. The room\nexpects sex. The room would be disappointed if it didn\xc2\x92t get sex. All of the\nother honeymoon suites would think it was a loser.'
Okay!'
Okay!'
(entering) Emily?!'
Nope, not under here!'
You didn\xc2\x92t find her?'
No, I\xc2\x92ve looked everywhere!'
Well, you couldn\xc2\x92t have looked everywhere or else you\nwould\xc2\x92ve found her!'
Yeah, I think you should keep looking!'
Yeah, for about 30 minutes.'
Wow, in 45 minutes you can find her twice. (Monica smiles at that.)'
No! For all I know, she\xc2\x92s trying to find me but couldn\xc2\x92t because\nI kept moving around. No, from now on, I\xc2\x92m staying in one place. (He sits down on the\nbed.) Right here.'
Well, it\xc2\x92s getting late.'
Yeah, we\xc2\x92re gonna go.'
Actually, do you guys mind staying here for a while?'
Ugh, y\xc2\x92know, umm we gotta get up early and catch that plane for New\nYork.'
Yeah, it\xc2\x92s a very large plane.'
(disappointed) That\xc2\x92s cool.'
But, we\xc2\x92ll stay here with you.'
Thanks guys! (They both sit down on either side of him.) I really\nappreciate this, y\xc2\x92know, but you don\xc2\x92t have to rub my butt.'
We have to leave for New York in an hour.'
I know, I\xc2\x92ve been looking at those doors, they look pretty sound\nproof, don\xc2\x92t you think?'
We can\xc2\x92t do that that\xc2\x92s insane. I mean \xc2\x91A\xc2\x92 he\ncould wake up and \xc2\x91B\xc2\x92 y\xc2\x92know, let\xc2\x92s go for it.'
Em-Emily? (Looking around for her.) Em-Emily? (He runs to the door.)\nEmily! (He opens the door to reveal the Walthams standing outside.)'
No.'
You can forget about Emily, she\xc2\x92s not with us.'
We\xc2\x92ve come for her things.'
Wait, well wh-wh-wh-where is she?'
She\xc2\x92s in hiding. She\xc2\x92s utterly humiliated. She\ndoesn\xc2\x92t want to see you ever again.'
We\xc2\x92re very sad that it didn\xc2\x92t work out between you and\nEmily, monkey. But, I think you\xc2\x92re absolutely delicious.'
Excuse me, I\xc2\x92m standing right here!'
Oh yes, there you are.'
(entering, carrying an armful of those little soaps.) Hey-hey, you guys\noh hurry up, get some, there\xc2\x92s a whole cart outside\xc2\x85 (Sees the Walthams and\nstops.)'
Goodbye Geller.'

Now, hold on! Hold on! (Stops him) Look, look, your daughter and I are
supposed to leave tonight for our honeymoon, now-now you-you tell her that I\xc2\x92m gonna
be at that airport and I hope that she\xc2\x92ll be there too! Oh yeah, I said Rachel\xc2\x92s
name, but it didn\xc2\x92t mean anything, Okay? She\xc2\x92s-she\xc2\x92s just a friend and
that\xc2\x92s all! (Rachel sits down, depressed.) That\xc2\x92s all! Now just tell Emily that
I love her and that I can\xc2\x92t imagine spending my life with anyone else. Please,
promise me that you\xc2\x92ll tell her that.'
All right, I\xc2\x92ll tell her. (To his wife) Come on bugger face!'
(As she walks pass Ross, she pats his but.) Call me.'
You spend half your life in the bathroom, why don\xc2\x92t you ever\ngo out the bloody window!'
Y\xc2\x92know, maybe it\xc2\x92s best that we never got to do it again.'
Yeah, it kinda makes that-that one night special. (Realizes something)\nY\xc2\x92know, technically we still are over international waters.'
I\xc2\x92m gonna go to the bathroom, maybe I\xc2\x92ll see you there in a\nbit?'
\xc2\x91Kay!'
Can I ask you something?'
Uhh, no.'
Felicity and I, we\xc2\x92re watching My Giant, and I was thinking,\n"I\xc2\x92m never gonna be as good an actor as that giant." Do you think I\xc2\x92m\njust wasting my life with this acting thing?'
No.'
I mean, the giant is like five years younger than me, y\xc2\x92know, you\nthink I\xc2\x92ll ever get there?'
Yes.'
Thanks man. '
Okay man. (Chandler starts to get up.)'
But what about how much taller he is than me?'

I mean, there\xc2\x92s no way I can make myself taller now, y\xc2\x92know? And\nwho knows what science will come up with in the future, but Chandler, what if I die an\nunsuccessful, regular sized man?'
Hey, Monica, wow you\xc2\x92ve been in the bathroom for like a half-hour.'
I know!'
Had the beef-tips, huh?'
Hey!'
Hey!'
Hi!'
(To Joey) You ate meat! (Joey is shocked) (To Chandler and Monica) You\nhad sex! (They\xc2\x92re shocked.)'
No we didn\xc2\x92t!'
I know you didn\xc2\x92t, I was talking about Monica.'
Phoebe, I did not have sex.'
This pregnancy is throwing me all off.'
All right, I\xc2\x92m gonna go say hi the chick and the duck.'
Oh, me too!'
Why would you need to say hi to them, you\xc2\x92ve been feeding them for\nfour days?'
Oh right, maybe I\xc2\x92ll just go home. '
Well, we certainly are alone.'
Yes! Good thing we have that, \xc2\x91Not in New York\xc2\x92 rule.'

Right. Umm, listen since we\xc2\x92re-we-re on that subject, umm, I just\nwanted to tell you that uh, well, I-I was going through a really hard time in London, what\nwith my brother getting married and that guy thinking I was Ross\xc2\x92s mother\xc2\x85'
Right.'
Well, an-anyway, I just\xc2\x97that night meant a lot to me, I guess\nI\xc2\x92m just trying to say thanks.'
Oh. Y\xc2\x92know, that night meant a lot to me too, and it wasn\xc2\x92t\nbecause I was in a bad place or anything, it just meant a lot to me \xc2\x91cause,\nyou\xc2\x92re really hot! Is that okay?'
(laughs) That\xc2\x92s okay.'
And I\xc2\x92m cute too.'
And you\xc2\x92re cute too.'
Thank you! (They hug.) All right, I gotta go unpack.'
Okay.'
Bye. '
(entering) I\xc2\x92m still on London time, does that count?'
That counts!'
Oh, good! (They start kissing.)'
Rach! Rach!'
(she stops and turns) Hi!'
Hi! What are you, what are you doing here?'
Well, I-I-I\xc2\x92ve been on Standby for a flight home for hours. '
Oh.'
Ohh, so no sign of Emily huh?'
Not yet.'
So umm, what time are you supposed to leave?'
(On the P.A.) This is the last call for Flight 1066 to\nAthens. The last call.'
Pretty soon I guess.'
Yeah. I\xc2\x92m sorry.'
I just, I don\xc2\x92t understand, I mean, how-how can she do this?\nY\xc2\x92know, what, am I, am I like a complete idiot for thinking that she\xc2\x92d actually\nshow up?'
No, you\xc2\x92re not an idiot, Ross. You\xc2\x92re a guy very much in love.'
Same difference.'
(On the P.A.) All ticketed passengers for Flight 1066 to\nAthens should now be on board.'
I get it! Well, that\xc2\x92s that.'
No, you know what, I think you should go.'
What?'
Yeah, I do. I think you should go, by yourself, get some distance, clear\nyour head, I think it\xc2\x92d be really good.'
Oh, I don\xc2\x92t, I don\xc2\x92t, I don\xc2\x92t know\xc2\x85'
Oh, come on Ross! I think it would be really good for you!'
I could, yeah, I can do that.'
Yeah.'
I can\xc2\x92t, I can\xc2\x92t even believe her! No, y\xc2\x92know what, I am, I\nam gonna go!'
Good!'
I know, why not?'
Right!'
Right?'
Right!'
Y\xc2\x92know\xc2\x97thanks! (They hug)'
Okay, I\xc2\x92ll see you back at home, if I ever get a flight out of\nhere.'
Yeah, well\xc2\x85nah.'
What? Wait, what?'
Why don\xc2\x92t you come, I mean, I-I have two tickets, why not?'
Well-well, I don\xc2\x92t know Ross\xc2\x97really?'
Yeah, yeah, it\xc2\x92ll be great! You can, you can lay on the beach and I\ncan cry over my failed marriage. See-see how I make jokes?'
Uh-huh.'
No really, I mean, I mean, God, I could use a friend.'
Oh wow, uh okay, uh maybe. Umm, yes, I can do that!'
Okay!'
Okay!'
Cool!'
All right!'
Come on! (They go to the jetway, Ross hands the tickets to the gate\nagent.) Here. '
Oh, okay, we\xc2\x92re going. Yeah.'
Ah! Ah! I forgot my jacket!'
Oh, wait-wait-wait\xc2\x85'
You tell them to wait!'
Okay. Wait! Wait!'
Emily.'
Oh no-no-no! Oh-no! (Emily starts to run out and Ross chases her.) No! No!\nEmily!'

Ahh, yes, I will have a glass of the Merlot and uh, (points to
Ross\xc2\x92s seat.) he will have a white wine spritzer. Woo! (Looks out the window.) Hey,
look at that, the airport\xc2\x92s moving. (Realizes that that\xc2\x92s not how it works.)
Hey, are we moving?! Are we moving? Why are we moving? Hey, time-out, umm, yeah, does the
captain know that we\xc2\x92re moving? (Sits back in defeat.) Oh my God. Oh, my gosh.'
